explanation:
Why each symbol is required to determine if memcmp is being (improperly) used on null-terminated strings:

- lfs_dir_traverse_filter: This function is explicitly installed as the cb callback inside lfs_dir_traverse. To prove the traversal itself does not directly or indirectly call memcmp on C strings, we must inspect this filter routine for any memcmp usage or string comparisons it performs on the buffers passed by lfs_dir_traverse.

- lfs_dir_compact, lfs_dir_splittingcompact, lfs_dir_relocatingcommit: These three functions are the static callers of lfs_dir_traverse (per the call graph). To fully analyze how lfs_dir_traverse is used in the system (what callback functions are passed and what buffer/content semantics are expected) we must inspect these callers to see which cb pointers and buffers they pass through — a caller could pass a callback that uses memcmp on a null-terminated string.

- struct lfs_attr: lfs_dir_traverse iterates user attributes and passes a[i].buffer and a[i].size to cb. The definition of struct lfs_attr (and its buffer semantics) is required to determine whether these buffers are NUL-terminated strings or binary buffers (i.e., whether comparing them with memcmp would implicitly be comparing strings).

- struct lfs_mattr: lfs_dir_traverse receives const struct lfs_mattr *attrs; the layout and meaning of this structure (mapping to struct lfs_attr or similar) is necessary to know what buffers are being handed to callbacks and whether they can be strings.

- struct lfs_mdir_t: The dir parameter and dir->pair/dir->off are used to read directory entries from storage. The structure definition is needed to understand what buffer values represent (disk metadata vs. C-strings) and whether any fields can be interpreted as null-terminated strings.

- struct lfs_dir_traverse: The stack stores copies of this structure and lfs_dir_traverse passes pointers to its fields (e.g. .tag, .buffer) as callback data. Its definition is required to understand the lifetime, types and semantics of .buffer and other fields that might reach code that could call memcmp.

- struct lfs_diskoff: lfs_dir_traverse sometimes sets buffer = &disk (a struct lfs_diskoff). The definition is required to know whether that structure may contain or point to NUL-terminated strings (it almost certainly does not, but the analysis must confirm) and to check whether code that receives a pointer to struct lfs_diskoff might misuse memcmp on it.

- lfs_tag_t, lfs_off_t: These typedefs define the types of tags and offsets passed to callbacks. Knowing their widths/semantics helps determine whether values passed to cb are interpreted as strings (unlikely) or numeric metadata.

- LFS_MKTAG, LFS_FROM_NOOP, LFS_FROM_MOVE, LFS_FROM_USERATTRS, LFS_TYPE_USERATTR, LFS_TYPE_STRUCT: These macros/constants are used heavily to construct and inspect tags and to distinguish user-attribute payloads from other data. To know when lfs_dir_traverse will pass attribute buffers (which could be strings) to cb (and when it will pass disk-offset structures), the tag encoding and the constants that describe tag types must be known. This is necessary to determine which buffer kinds can reach code that might call memcmp on strings.

In short: to decide whether memcmp is (improperly) used to compare NUL-terminated strings in the context of lfs_dir_traverse, you must inspect (1) the callback(s) that are actually invoked (especially lfs_dir_traverse_filter and any callbacks installed by the callers), (2) the data structures that define what buffers are (struct lfs_attr, struct lfs_mattr, struct lfs_diskoff, struct lfs_mdir_t, struct lfs_dir_traverse), and (3) the tag encoding macros/constants that determine when attribute buffers (potential strings) are handed to callbacks. These symbols are the minimum set required to follow the dataflow from lfs_dir_traverse to any code that might call memcmp on a null-terminated string.
